results.title: Bram Stoker's Dracula
results.brief_description: Francis Ford Coppola’s lavish new version of Bram Stoker’s classic novel is visually stunning, filled with images of both beauty and horror. Dracula is played brilliantly by Gary Oldman, and his archrival Dr. Van Helsing is played by Sir Anthony Hopkins.

constellations_other.name: Shadowplay and spookiness
constellations_other.description: Silhouettes and shadows scare up some of the most sinister creatures in cinema and videogames.

constellations_other.name: Clothing, country, character
constellations_other.description: Edie Kurzer's costume design work on Judy & Punch and Picnic at Hanging Rock is part of a larger trend in Australian films and TV series.

results.description: Francis Ford Coppola’s lavish new version of Bram Stoker’s classic novel is visually stunning, filled with images of both beauty and horror. James V. Hart’s screenplay sticks fairly close to Stoker’s novel although costuming and special effects give this film a very definite contemporary feel. Dracula is played brilliantly by Gary Oldman, and his arch-rival Dr. Van Helsing is played by Sir Anthony Hopkins. Also stars Winona Ryder and Keanu Reeves.
description_for_label: Francis Ford Coppola’s lavish new version of Bram Stoker’s classic novel is visually stunning, filled with images of both beauty and horror. James V. Hart’s screenplay sticks fairly close to Stoker’s novel although costuming and special effects give this film a very definite contemporary feel. Dracula is played brilliantly by Gary Oldman, and his arch-rival Dr. Van Helsing is played by Sir Anthony Hopkins. Also stars Winona Ryder and Keanu Reeves.

results.title: Brake free
results.brief_description: This film is designed to encourage imagination and story telling by children. A small boy imagines himself as a railwayman, a train and a driver of the old cog railway that climbs Mt Washington. No narration or dialogue - only sound effects and a musical score.

results.title: Braindead = Dead alive (D)
results.creator_credit: Wingnut Films, Jim Booth and Peter Jackson
results.brief_description: New Zealand director Peter Jackson has aptly described “Braindead’s” anarchic style as splatstick, an outrageous melding of extreme gore and physical humour. While it does go to great lengths to gross you out (you’ll never eat porridge again!), it still finds time to be a rather sweet love story, as well as a titanic Oedipal struggle between mother and son. Set in the latter part of the fifties, “Braindead” concerns momma’s boy Lionel’s (Timothy Balme) feeble attempts to break away from his domineering mother (Elizabeth Moody), while a romance develops between him and local shop girl, Paquita (Diana Penalver). The situation gets messy however when Lionel’s mother is bitten by a strange rat like monkey (captured in a very funny opening sequence) which turns her into one of the living dead. When Lionel’s lecherous uncle Les (Ian Watkin) shows up unexpectedly, all hell breaks loose and soon the place is swarming with zombies.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Wingnut Films, Jim Booth and Peter Jackson

results.title: Brain story. Eps. 04-06
results.creator_credit: BBC, Sam Roberts, Thecla Schreuders and Zoe Heron
results.brief_description: Brain Story is a series of six programs exploring the latest research on brain function. Professor Susan Greenfield CBE, presenter of the series, uses current scientific technology to help answer a number of philosophical questions about who we are as people and what makes you ‘you’ and the brain’s role in this. Episode 4: “First amongst equals” investigates why humans use their brains beyond survival instincts. The frontal lobes in our brain controls our ability to plan and make goals. An extensive study of chimpanzees and their language ability is used to illustrate the difference between animal and human brain function and why we as humans seek to excel beyond survival. Episode 5: “Growing the mind” explores how memory is developed throughout our lives, the physical conditions to facilitate this in the brain and how beyond ‘semantic memory’ our memory defines us as individuals. Episode 6: “The Final mystery” explores vividly how the brain creates the conscious experience of being you. Greenfield establishes how our daily actions are the result of slowly emerging sub-conscious processes in the brain. (Episode 6 features The Jim Rose Circus).

results.title: Brain story. Eps. 01-03
results.creator_credit: BBC, Andrew Cohen and Sam Starbuck
results.brief_description: ‘Brain Story’ is a series of six programs exploring the latest research on brain function. Professor Susan Greenfield CBE, presenter of the series, uses current scientific technology to help answer a number of philosophical questions about who we are as people and what makes you ‘you’ and the brain’s role in this. Episode 1: “All in the mind” introduces the series and addresses broadly the range of functions that the brain is responsible for from spirituality to the very nature of conscious experience. Episode 2: “In the heat of the moment” explores what makes life worth living and asks whilst looking at the range of human emotions ‘How does the brain create intense feelings of love, fear, anger and joy?’. Episode 3: “The Mind’s Eye” explores how the brain generates vision. Movement, shape, colour and size are all constructed in our mind. The brain processes very little of what we see because our eyes are slaves to our attention system. “The Mind’s eye” concerns itself with illusion and reality and how our brain interprets and influences our perception.

results.title: Brain sex. Episode 3
results.creator_credit: Primedia Productions, Quality Time TV, Primetime Television, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, Discovery Channel, Cheryl Knapp, Ann Moir and Jonathan Harris
results.brief_description: The final program in this series looks primarily at the sexual behaviour of men and women, how it differs, and each sex’s perceptions of the opposite sex’s motivation. It also looks at more differences between the female and male brains, particularly in relation to aging, and relationships with the opposite sex.

results.title: Brain sex. Episode 2
results.creator_credit: Primedia Productions, Quality Time TV, Primetime Television, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, Discovery Channel, Ann Moir and Jonathan Harris
results.brief_description: This program looks at differences between the two genders, both real and perceived, and the new discoveries by researchers into the brain, which suggest that these differences are due to physical differences in the male and female brain. How much of our behaviour is predetermined and how much can be learnt or modified should perhaps be reassessed in the light of these discoveries, and new attitudes to difference and equality formed.

results.title: Brain sex. Episode 1
results.creator_credit: Primedia Productions, Quality Time TV, Primetime Television, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, Discovery Channel and Jonathan Harris
results.brief_description: Our chromosomes are decided at conception, and shortly thereafter hormones start to play their part in determining sex. This program investigates the role that hormones play in determining sex and sexual characteristics, including behaviour patterns. Can hormones change brain structure? Does the brain determine gender related characteristics? The program looks at studies of children who suffer from Turner’s syndrome and CAH syndrome as we attempt to unravel the roles of nature and nurture in patterns of behaviour.

results.title: Brain is the reason
results.brief_description: A backyard barbecue forms the background for a presentation explaining how alcohol affects judgment and reason and why drinking may cause accidents and death.

results.title: Brahms and his music
results.brief_description: Recreates Brahm’s life among scenes closely associated with his development as a composer. These include Vienna, where he reached the height of his career, and the German countryside he loved. Excerpts from the following are included: Sonata No.3 in F for Piano; Symphony No.1; Symphony No.2, and the D Major Violin Concerto.
